docs.lead_paragraph: Joan Crawford will be portrayed by Faye Dunaway in the film ''Mommie Dearest,'' based on the book by Miss Crawford's daughter, Christina.

headline.main: Faye Dunaway to Portray Joan Crawford in Movie

docs.snippet: THIS season's programs by the Jupiter Symphony are combining chamber music with orchestral works, and the first of these amalgamations took place in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night. The focal point of the evening was the violinist Oscar Shumsky, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: THIS season's programs by the Jupiter Symphony are combining chamber music with orchestral works, and the first of these amalgamations took place in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night. The focal point of the evening was the violinist Oscar Shumsky, who first appeared as the lone performer of Bach's Unaccompanied Partita in B minor (BWV 1002). After easily dispatching this difficult assignment, he gradually welcomed an increasing number of instrumental participants, first to play a Mozart Trio (in E flat, K. 498) and then concertos by Bach (in A minor, BWV 1041) and Mozart (in B flat, K. 207).

docs.snippet: Spain's center-right ruling party, jolted by the resignation of Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez, ended an occasionally acrimonious three-day congress today without having resolved major organizational and ideological differences.   An open struggle f...
docs.lead_paragraph: Spain's center-right ruling party, jolted by the resignation of Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez, ended an occasionally acrimonious three-day congress today without having resolved major organizational and ideological differences. An open struggle for control of the Union of the Democratic Center's executive committee was decided in favor of former Suarez loyalists, who beat back challenges by rightists who are close to an increasingly active Roman Catholic Church hierarchy. But the dissidents, who believe that only an unambiguous move to the right can avoid electoral disaster for the party, mustered impressive strength on a number of votes.

headline.main: SPAIN'S RULING PARTY ENDS PARLEY WITH ITS RANKS STILL BADLY DIVIDED

byline.original: By JAMES M. MARKHAM, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LES Grands Ballets Canadiens from Montreal, last seen in New York a decade ago with its smash-hit, ''Tommy,'' returned for an all-toobrief appearance last weekend at the Herbert H. Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts.   That there is of ...
docs.lead_paragraph: LES Grands Ballets Canadiens from Montreal, last seen in New York a decade ago with its smash-hit, ''Tommy,'' returned for an all-toobrief appearance last weekend at the Herbert H. Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts. That there is of course, more to this company than rock ballets was obvious in even the first of the two programs on view here. Friday night's selection consisted of George Balanchine's ''Concerto Barocco,'' Brian Macdonald's ''Double Quartet'' and ''Tam Ti Delam'' and Milko Sparemblek's ''The Miraculous Mandarin.'' This kind of touring repertory, which includes American modern dance on other programs, invites the label of eclecticism. Yet it also suggests an artistic profile that distinguishes Les Grands Ballets Canadiens from Canada's other two major ballet companies. Toronto's National Ballet of Canada has recently concentrated on the 19th-century classics and a British repertory. The Royal Winnipeg Ballet appears to focus on 20th-century classics and contemporary dance drama, spotlighting Oscar Araiz's work.

docs.snippet: President Reagan appealed for sweeping reductions in spending and taxes, asserting that only such action would avert ''an economic calamity of tremendous proportions.'' The President went on television to build support for the economic plan that t...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Reagan appealed for sweeping reductions in spending and taxes, asserting that only such action would avert ''an economic calamity of tremendous proportions.'' The President went on television to build support for the economic plan that the Administration will propose to Congress. ''The old business-as-usual treatment can't save us,'' Mr. Reagan said.

docs.snippet: LAST St. Valentine's Day, instead of fattening my body with chocolates from a heart-shaped box, I decided to enrich my mind with heart-sprinkled poetry. I discovered a feast of allusions to that anatomical pump, deliciously confusing and paradoxic...
docs.lead_paragraph: LAST St. Valentine's Day, instead of fattening my body with chocolates from a heart-shaped box, I decided to enrich my mind with heart-sprinkled poetry. I discovered a feast of allusions to that anatomical pump, deliciously confusing and paradoxical, more than enough to sate the most voracious literary appetite. Just what is a heart? To Lewis Carroll, ''nothing so much as a bowl/Brimming over with quivering curds.'' William Sharp's ''heart is a lonely hunter.'' Hawthorne compares ''one's own heart'' to the darkest dungeon. Nathalia Crane, in contrast, equates her fluttering heart to ''the washing on the line'' and Shakespeare compares the heart to a bell, and the tongue to the clapper.

headline.main: A VALENTINE SELECTION OF BON MOTS

byline.original: By KAY McKEMY; Kay McKemy lives in Armonk

docs.snippet: When El Salvador's long-awaited leftist offensive faltered soon after it was launched last month, not even the United States-backed junta claimed that the guerrillas had been defeated.  They had failed to injure the armed forces or to spark a nati...
docs.lead_paragraph: When El Salvador's long-awaited leftist offensive faltered soon after it was launched last month, not even the United States-backed junta claimed that the guerrillas had been defeated. They had failed to injure the armed forces or to spark a nationwide strike and popular insurrection, but the rebels seemed no closer to surrender. The leftist forces withdrew to the mountains and began regrouping. If they fail in their next push, their leaders said privately, they hope at least to win a place at the bargaining table. And if there are no negotiations, they will revert to ''prolonged popular war.'' Washington seemed to agree that the guerrillas remain a threat. It renewed military aid to the junta last month, arguing that the guerrillas were receiving arms from Cuba and Nicaragua. For the first time in three years, the United States sent ''lethal'' equipment, notably helicopter gunships and automatic rifles for the expanding army. A small cadre of American advisers was also on the scene.

headline.main: SALVADOR GUERILLAS HAVE NEITHER WON-NOR LOST

docs.snippet: heir creations don't stop traffic or make temperatures rise. The fire of spontaneity is banked - they are apt to make clothes more like tempered steel than molten lava. But what this select group of fashion designers does offer is extraordinary: q...
docs.lead_paragraph: heir creations don't stop traffic or make temperatures rise. The fire of spontaneity is banked - they are apt to make clothes more like tempered steel than molten lava. But what this select group of fashion designers does offer is extraordinary: quality, serenity, comfort, elegant simplicity - and, above all, a special kind of intelligence. They might be called, for want of a better word, cerebral. Among those who practice their craft in the fashion capitals, the most prominent names include Giorgio Armani and Gianfranco Ferre of Milan, Karl Lagerfeld and Sonia Rykiel of Paris and Geoffrey Beene, Ronaldus Shamask and Zoran of New York. Two sometime members of the fold are Perry Ellis of New York, whose work alternates between triumphant logic and flights of fancy, and Paris's Yves Saint Laurent, the master, whose every collection contains its share of simple, strong designs.

docs.snippet: Whether as ''Caterer,'' ''Food Designer'' or ''Gastronomic Technical Adviser,'' the names of people who provide on-camera edibles may soon be permanent fixtures in the growing list of screen credits that follow the film. Not long ago, the Cafe Roy...
docs.lead_paragraph: Whether as ''Caterer,'' ''Food Designer'' or ''Gastronomic Technical Adviser,'' the names of people who provide on-camera edibles may soon be permanent fixtures in the growing list of screen credits that follow the film. Not long ago, the Cafe Royal in London and a host of other haute cuisine concerns took bows for the food that became a menu for murder in ''Who Is Killing the Great Chefs of Europe?'' Soon, audiences may routinely learn who put the hamburger, as well as the foie gras, under the klieg lights. Movie food has come a long way since James Cagney pushed a halfgrapefruit into Mae Clark's face in the 1931 classic, ''The Public Enemy.'' Along with makeup, hair styles, costumes and sets, food is becoming a favorite prop, relied on to establish character and mood. There is nothing new about the use of eating scenes in films to convey impressions of celebration, comedy, tragedy, poverty, gluttony or luxurious sensuality. Now, however, the camera focuses tightly on a particular food or dish, making it readily identifiable, and an effective symbol.

headline.main: FOOD BUILDS CHARACTER' MOVIE MAKERS DISCOVER Times'
